instruction: What modifications were made to the basic workflow in the evaluation of GPR models for predicting spring wheat parameters using hyperspectral data?
Output:
The modifications made to the basic workflow in the evaluation of GPR models for predicting spring wheat parameters using hyperspectral data were:

1. Removal of soil pixels from the images prior to training: This modification involved excluding soil pixels from the training data to improve the accuracy of the predictions.

2. Data fusion with apparent soil electrical conductivity measurements: This modification involved combining hyperspectral data with measurements of apparent soil electrical conductivity. The fusion of these two types of data improved the performance of the models in predicting nitrogen uptake and nitrogen content.

3. Replacing the Euclidean distance in the GPR covariance function with the spectral angle distance: This modification involved using the spectral angle distance instead of the Euclidean distance in the GPR covariance function. This change aimed to enhance the accuracy of the predictions.

These modifications were evaluated to determine their impact on the accuracy of the GPR models in estimating spring wheat parameters.

instruction: Can the accuracy of GPR models in estimating spring wheat parameters be improved by using spectroscopic methods compared to traditional methods?
Output:
Yes, the accuracy of GPR models in estimating spring wheat parameters can be improved by using spectroscopic methods compared to traditional methods. The study mentioned in the text evaluated the accuracy of GPR models in estimating spring wheat dry matter, nitrogen content, and nitrogen uptake. It found that models trained on hyperspectral data from two different types of cameras (a french Fabry-Perot interferometer camera and a push-broom scanner) using the squared exponential covariance function showed the most accurate predictions for nitrogen uptake. 

The study also explored modifications to the basic workflow, including the removal of soil pixels from the images prior to training, data fusion with apparent soil electrical conductivity measurements, and replacing the Euclidean distance in the GPR covariance function with the spectral angle distance. Among these modifications, data fusion improved the performance in predicting nitrogen uptake and nitrogen content.

Furthermore, the study found that the estimation accuracy of nitrogen content varied considerably across the two hyperspectral cameras. Satisfactory predictions for nitrogen content were obtained only in the data-fusion scenario, and only with a high spectral resolution push-broom device capable of capturing longer wavelengths, up to 1000 nm.

Overall, the study concluded that the accuracy of GPR models in estimating spring wheat parameters can be improved by using spectroscopic methods
